title: 115_hr1940
content:
The "Right to Rent Act of 2017" allows individuals the right to rent a home subject to foreclosure. The "Right to Rent Act of 2017" grants eligible mortgagors the option to continue occupying foreclosed property for up to 5 years after providing notice, subject to certain requirements. The "Right to Rent Act of 2017" allows eligible mortgagors to stay in foreclosed property for up to 5 years after receiving written notice from the foreclosing creditor, outlining default on the mortgage and the commencement of foreclosure. The mortgagor has the right to continue occupying the property under specific terms. The "Right to Rent Act of 2017" allows eligible mortgagors to stay in foreclosed property for up to 5 years after receiving written notice from the foreclosing creditor. The mortgagor must pay fair market rent monthly and use the property as their principal residence. SEC. 3. REQUIRED NOTICE.

Notice for eligible mortgages must be in writing, delivered to the court and foreclosing creditor, stating the mortgagor's intent to stay in the foreclosed property.

SEC. 4. DETERMINATION OF FAIR MARKET RENT. The fair market rent for a foreclosed property in a covered foreclosure proceeding is determined by the court and adjusted annually based on changes in the Consumer Price Index. Owners can request a redetermination of the fair market rent. The court allows for redetermination of the fair market rent for a foreclosed property, with costs covered by the requesting party. No redetermination can be made within 12 months of the most recent one conducted for the same party. SEC. 5. Nonjudicial foreclosure proceedings allow eligible mortgagors to seek fair market rent determination in court. SEC. 6 clarifies that this Act does not impede creditors' right to foreclose on a mortgage. SEC. 7 grants the right to reinstatement. SEC. 7 grants eligible mortgagors the right to reinstatement of an eligible mortgage under contract or State law. SEC. 8 allows eligible mortgagors to choose to have proceedings under section 4 or 5 moved to the appropriate district court of the United States. SEC. 9 clarifies that this Act does not affect State law. SEC. 9 clarifies that this Act does not affect State laws on foreclosure or landlord-tenant relationships. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development oversees compliance with the Act, assists eligible mortgagors, conducts outreach activities, and submits annual reports to Congress. For the purposes of this Act, definitions include "covered foreclosure proceeding" for eligible mortgages, "eligible mortgagor" as the borrower, and "eligible mortgage" as a first or subordinate mortgage on a single-family property used as the borrower's principal residence for at least 2 years. The eligible mortgage must have a purchase price lower than the median price for residences in the same area and originated on or before December 31, 2008. The terms "foreclosed property" and "foreclosing creditor" are defined in relation to covered foreclosure proceedings. The median purchase price of residences in a metropolitan area or State is determined by information from the National Association of Realtors for the most recent month available. The term "owner" in a foreclosed property refers to the person with title after the foreclosure proceeding, including successors or assigns. A "single family property" can be a structure with 1 to 4 units, a unit in a multi-unit condo with common areas, or a unit in a project where purchase of stock allows permanent occupancy. SEC. 12. APPLICABILITY AND SUNSET. This Act applies to ongoing foreclosure proceedings at enactment but expires after 5 years for new proceedings.
